Mental Demand: How much mental and perceptual activity was required while using RAMPA?
(Was the task easy or demanding, simple or complex?)
column38: Physical Demand: How much physical activity was required while using RAMPA? (Was the task easy or demanding, slack or strenuous?)
column39: Temporal Demand: How much time pressure did you feel due to the pace at which the tasks or task elements occurred while using RAMPA? (Was the pace slow or rapid?)
column40: Own Performance: How successful were you in performing the task while using RAMPA? (How satisfied were you with your performance?)
column41: Effort: How hard did you have to work (mentally and physically) to accomplish your level of performance while using RAMPA?
column42: Frustration Level: How irritated, stressed, and annoyed (versus content, relaxed, and complacent) did you feel during the task while using RAMPA?

column56: pinch recognition is buggy, drawn trajectories cannot be edited other than being erased/trimmed and redrawn, trajectory was being drawn at an offset to my pinch position once, we had to reopen the software a couple of times for various technical reasons
column57: I think it would be much better if the initially recorded trajectory is just a first draft, and the user can smooth the line at a level of intensity they choose and/or mold/edit it from its control points (i.e., making a hill-like curve more shallow or steep). Hand-tracked trajectory drawing can also be replaced with controller-tracked drawing, since that’d probably be more reliable.
column60: I think it would be much more intuitive for humans to simply demonstrate how they do the task themselves. The dream-product would then capture the *effects* of that demonstration, distill it down to the core/aimed effects that we can call the “intent”, and then find out how the robot arm may accomplish that same intent with its own capabilities. That’s perhaps a completely different direction, but this experiment leaves the human subject wishing just for that dream-product.

column54: Despite my experience in the domain, it is intimidating even for me to manually control robotic manipulators, especially industrial ones, as they are heavy and expensive. RAMPA simplifies the data collection part of LfD and speeds up my research.

column57: Some trajectory needed to be drawn precisely, option to restrict drawing on some axis to constant values may help the user. Auto detecting the end points and prompting user to confrm for CNMP test may be convenient.

column10: I am a research assistant working on robotics for 4 years. I worked on hardware and software development of aerial robots and mobile ground robots pertaining control, visual positioning and mapping problems. I have worked on robotic arms a little for tasks requiring high movement accuracy.

column60: Prior explanation regarding which part of the robot follows the desired trajectory would improve my experience during trajectory generation with AR. Application UI could be simpler, containing only necessary options for a user. I did not know how accurate my trajectories should be for the obstacle-avoid trajectory generation part, which increased my mental pressure.
